title: 114_s684
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2015" may increase per diem payments for transitional housing assistance that becomes permanent housing for homeless veterans. Section 2012(a)(2) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to redesignate subparagraphs and adjust rates for transitional housing assistance for homeless veterans. The maximum rate of per diem for services provided to homeless veterans placed in permanent housing is 150 percent of the rate authorized for State homes for domiciliary care. Authorization of per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may enter partnerships with public or private entities to fund legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, ensuring equitable distribution across the US, including rural areas and tribal lands. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related legal assistance, family law support, income support services, and criminal defense for issues like outstanding warrants and driver's license revocation to reduce recidivism and aid in reentry. The Secretary may consult with public and private entities to develop partnerships for legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Entities entering into partnerships may be required to submit periodic reports on the legal services provided. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance or care under specific sections of the United States Code are outlined in subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance or care under specific sections of the United States Code are outlined in subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38. The Secretary may disregard breaks in the continuity of assistance or care for which the veteran is not responsible. SEC. 6 amends Section 2023 of title 38 by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 7 extends financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing by adding $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2016. SEC. 8 requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to evaluate comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must assess and measure the capacity of programs for homeless veterans receiving grants or per diem payments. This assessment includes examining national and local levels to determine if there is enough capacity to meet the needs of homeless veterans in each geographic area and subpopulations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs assesses program capacity for homeless veterans to ensure effective service delivery, set goals, allocate funding, and improve referrals. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of completing the assessment, including recommendations to enhance programs and per diem payments for homeless veterans. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of this Act. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Additionally, the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans will be repealed. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed, and the corresponding item in the table of sections is removed.
